de.brands4friends.daleq.core

Interface Table


  • public interface Table
    Used to build the content of a relational database table.

    Logically a Table is a container which holds a list of Rows. Technically this is a Builder to declarative describe the content of the database table. Therefore it provides a set of builder methods to construct the rows. Besides the obvious #with, which accepts a list of rows, there are several methods which add rows just from a set of given ids, to be provide a concise mechanism to fill the database table. Together with Row it defines Daleq's model to describe the content of a database table.

    TODO describe the table's meta model.

    Use Daleq.aTable(java.lang.Class<T>) to create a Table. We encourage to static import this method to benefit from Daleq's embedded DSL.

    See Also:
    Daleq, Row

      Table withRowsUntil(long maxId)
      Deprecated. 
      The method was supposed to be used for convenience, but meanwhile we learned that it is not intuitive. On one hand it is not a good idea to start ids form 0, because some DBs treat 0 as an id special, especially in combination with sequences. For instance, Mysql will not let you explicitly set a a field, which has the auto increment attribute, with a zero, only non zero values could be set explicitly. On the other hand, specifying the maxId as an exclusive interval is not intuitive in this context. Use withRowsBetween(long, long) instead.

      Adds rows with the given ids to the table.

    • Method Detail

      • with

        Table with(Row... rows)
        Adds rows to the table.

        For instance 

        aTable(ProductTable.class)
 .rows(
 aRow(1).f(SIZE,"XL"),
 aRow(2)
 )
        will yield a table containing
        IDNAMESIZEPRICE
        1?XL?
        2???
        Parameters:
        rows - all rows which should be added to the table
        Returns:
        a Table containing the new rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if one instance of rows is null.

      • withSomeRows

        Table withSomeRows(java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Long> ids)
        Adds rows with the given ids to the table.

        A convenience method, which transforms each id in ids to a row, like aRow(id) would do, and adds it to the already existing rows in the table.

        For instance 

        final List<Long> ids = Lists.newArrayList(1L,2L);
 aTable(ProductTable.class).withSomeRows(ids);
        will yield a table
        IDNAMESIZEPRICE
        1???
        2???
        Parameters:
        ids - the ids of those rows, which will be added to the table.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the new rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the parameter ids or one element in it is null

      • withSomeRows

        Table withSomeRows(long... ids)
        Adds rows with the given ids to the table.

        A convenience method, which transforms each id in ids to a row, like aRow(id) would do, and adds it to the already existing rows in the table.

        For instance 

        aTable(ProductTable.class).withSomeRows(1L, 2L);
        will yield a table
        IDNAMESIZEPRICE
        1???
        2???
        Parameters:
        ids - the ids of those rows, which will be added to the table.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the new rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if either the parameter ids or one element in it is null

      • withRowsUntil

        @Deprecated
Table withRowsUntil(long maxId)
        Deprecated. The method was supposed to be used for convenience, but meanwhile we learned that it is not intuitive. On one hand it is not a good idea to start ids form 0, because some DBs treat 0 as an id special, especially in combination with sequences. For instance, Mysql will not let you explicitly set a a field, which has the auto increment attribute, with a zero, only non zero values could be set explicitly. On the other hand, specifying the maxId as an exclusive interval is not intuitive in this context. Use withRowsBetween(long, long) instead.
        Adds maxId number of rows with the ids from 0 to maxId - 1 to the table.

        The method should not be used anymore and will be removed in future releases.

        Parameters:
        maxId - describes the upper (exclusive) limit of the ids which will be added, starting form 0.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the new rows.

      • withRowsBetween

        Table withRowsBetween(long from,
                    long to)
        Adds rows with all ids in the interval [from,to] to the table.

        A convience method, which assumes an interval starting at from up to and including to and consisting of all ids in between. Each id in this interval will be transformed to a row, like aRow(id) would do it and add it to the table.

        For instance 

        aTable(ProductTable.class).withRowsBetween(1L, 4L);
        will yield a table
        IDNAMESIZEPRICE
        1???
        2???
        3???
        4???
        Parameters:
        from - the lower inclusive bound of the interval. Has to be >=0.
        to - the upper inclusive bound of the internval. Has to be >=0 and from < to.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the new rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if not
        1. from >=0
        2. to >=0
        3. from < to

      • having

        Table having(FieldTypeReference field,
           java.lang.Object... values)
        Sets the field in all already existing rows to the given values.

        A convenience method to batch change all already existing rows in the table. It is expected that field belongs to this Table's TableDef. However, this is not checked while being added to the table, but only when build() is called.

        The already existing rows are expected to have the order in which they were added. The values are applied to all those rows in that order. Hence the respective field in the i-th row will get the i-th value from values. If there are more rows than values, than only the first rows get their fields set, the other rows will not have their field changed. On the other hand, i there are more values than rows, only the first values are used to be assigned to the rows.

        Note that rows added to the table after this method has been called, will not be affected by it.

        Parameters:
        field - References the field, which is expected to be contained in code>Table's TableDef. The respective fields in all rows in the table, will be changed.
        values - the values will be assigned to the respective field in all rows, already existing in the table. The value could be of any type Daleq is able to convert. See Row for further details.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the changed rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if field is null

      • allHaving

        Table allHaving(FieldTypeReference field,
              @Nullable
              java.lang.Object value)
        Sets the field in all already existing rows the same given value.

        A convenience method to batch change all already existing rows in the table. It is expected that field belongs to this Table's TableDef. However, this is not checked while being added to the table, but only when build() is called.

        All rows in the table get their field updated with the given value

        Note that rows added to the table after this method has been called, will not be affected by it.

        Parameters:
        field - References the field, which is expected to be contained in code>Table's TableDef. The respective fields in all rows in the table, will be changed.
        value - the value will be assigned to the respective field in all rows, already existing in the table. The value could be of any type Daleq is able to convert. See Row for further details.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the changed rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if field is null

      • havingIterable

        Table havingIterable(FieldTypeReference field,
                   java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Object> values)
        Sets the field in all already existing rows to the given values.

        A convenience method to batch change all already existing rows in the table.

        Parameters:
        field - References the field, which is expected to be contained in code>Table's TableDef. The respective fields in all rows in the table, will be changed.
        values - the values will be assigned to the respective field in all rows, already existing in the table. The value could be of any type Daleq is able to convert. See Row for further details.
        Returns:
        a Table containing the changed rows.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if field or values is null
        See Also:
        having(FieldTypeReference, Object...)

      • build

        TableData build(Context context)
        Constructs the actual data holding entities.

        Since Table is actually a builder, at some point it has to construct the entities, holding the database table content. In general this method is not expected to be called by client code, but only by Daleq's internal code.

        Parameters:
        context - provides contextual information, which are required to build a TableData
        Returns:
        an entity actually holding the database table content
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if context is null
        NoSuchDaleqFieldException - if any row in the table contains a field which does not belong to the table's meta model.
